BitTorrent ...:::::::::: Privacy and Security Guide: ::::::::::... 


Hi, everyone. 


This is a guide explaining the basic safety of Bit Torrent and methods of concealment, which makes it difficult on the Internet for people as well as ISP curious to Bit Torrent (torrent) of interpret traffic and trade, or even make you catch something on your PC you should not! :-p 

First, I wrote this guide solely for the Torrent protocol that I believe to be the only way to share files safe and fast, given that potentially BitTorrent consumes at least 60% of all ISP bandwidth, many of people agree on this, but I obviously can deceive me! :-p 

The sharing of data files is available for transfer from point A to point B, it is usually means my P2P (peer-to-peer), the files are stored on and served by personal computers of users 
Let me make this point, the file sharing itself is not illegal if copyright is shared, it is, but when it is not, as his right to go to church, it does should not frown on BitTorrent, it is, is a protocol for transferring data to get data from point A to point B. 

I am not responsible for what you do with this guide, this guide is to keep you safe! 

I think it is my right to my privacy, if your neighbor has begun to spy on what you have in your trunk, or watch while you put your clothes on the clothesline, you can be concerned, but you want to give a firm commitment in the face with the front of a shovel, this is not your fault, blame human nature. 

So why is it different for the world of the Internet?, Well, it does not! 

When people begin to watch what you do! 
Such a bad thing either! 

That is why it is your job to stop this situation, I wrote this simple guide to help you ensure your safety when using Bit Torrent, what choice you make, whether acquire a license or copyright protected material or whatever, if you are unsure, you will face the consequences of your actions, you can greatly reduce this risk by following what is written in this guide, to enjoy with friends. 

...:::::::::: Encryption Protocol Bit Torrent ::::::::::... 


Protocol encryption (PE) and the current message encryption (MSE) 

PE and PRO are implemented in the BT client Azureus, ÃƒÅ½Ã‚Â¼Torrent, BitComet, KTorrent and Mainline. 

PE and PRO methods are darkening protocol, they use a DH key exchange combined with information hash of the stream to create the key, it uses RC4 to encrypt the data. 

The DH key exchange will minimize the risk of passive listening, and the info hash to avoid man-in-the-middle attacks. RC4 is chosen for its speed. The first kilobyte of the RC4 output is discarded to prevent an attack. 

The specification allows users to choose between encrypting the headers or the full connection. Encrypting the full connection provides more obfuscation but uses more CPU time. 

However, only Azureus and ÃƒÅ½Ã‚Â¼Torrent beta 1.4.1 build 413 or more allows the user to choose. All other clients default to full encryption. 
To ensure compatibility with other clients that do not support this specification, users can also choose whether the input or output connections are permitted without encryption (Inheritance connections). 

All customers will support encryption automatically if they are leaving an encrypted connection, even if encryption is disabled. 

Now, how do these things: 

If you use Azureus: 
  
1. Go to: Tools> Options> Connection> Transport Encryption 

2. Check the 'require encrypted transport box. 

3. Choose RC4 in the "Minimum encryption" drop-down menu 

(*** RC4 uses more CPU time than the plain encryption or no encryption, but it is much more efficient **) 

4. You can choose to tick the "Allow non-encrypted outgoing connections if the connection attempt is not encrypted 'box. 
This will ensure compatibility with clients that are not using encryption. 

However, it will be easier for your ISP to detect Bit Torrent traffic. It is recommended that you try to tick this box first. If you still get a good speed to uncheck it. 

5. Check the "Allow non-encrypted connections" box 
  

Made. 

If you use BitComet: 
  
1. Go to: Options> Preferences> Advanced> Connection 

2. Go to: 'Protocol encryption' You can choose between "automatic detection" and "always." Automatically give you more connections but offers less protection against traffic shapers. 
She recommends trying to auto-detect first, if not increase your speed, you need to change: always (Always). 
  

Made. 

If you use BitTorrent or ÃƒÅ½Ã‚Â¼Torrent: 
   
1. Go to: Options> Preferences> Bittorrent (or Network for ÃƒÅ½Ã‚Â¼Torrent). 
  
2. Go to 'Protocol encryption (or encryption for ÃƒÅ½Ã‚Â¼Torrent), you can choose between "enabled" and "forced". 'Enabled' will give you more connections but offers less protection against traffic shapers. 
It is nessesaire to "On" at a minimum, I recommend to put "forced", but if you wanted to increase your speed, uncheck it, but know that you lost in quality of "camouflage" ;-) 

3. Check "Allow legacy incoming connections' allows non ECRYPT customers to connect to you. This improves compatibility between clients but makes you more vulnerable 
I recommend to check this box, but if you wanted to increase your speed, uncheck it, but know that you lost in quality of "camouflage" ;-) 

Made. 

You have now reached a higher level of anonimat while using Bit Torrent, but this is not finished, the hardest part is done, I assure you.

Why Teredo blocking is important 

All Windows Vista machines come with a service called "Teredo" enabled by default. This allows you to access the IPv6 internet using IPv4. It also means that any IPv4 user can move to IPv6 in order to evade IP blockers and firewalls. 

PeerGuardian fully detects these types of uses of IPv6 and checked regularly against blocking.

Start -> All Programs -> Accessories -> Command Prompt: right click -> Run as administrator. 

Copy the following exactly: 

Bcdedit / set loadoptions DDISABLE_INTEGRITY_CHECKS 

Right-click on the title bar, go to Edit -> Paste. Make sure what was pasted is correct, then press Enter to execute the command 

Reboot
